commit_message:
Tempest API tests using testscenarios for create/update pool

Included Tempest data-driven tests for validating attributes when:

(1)create pool with different scenarios
(2)update pool 'admin_state_up' as False with different scenarios

Contains 8 scenarios tests in-order to set admin_state_up
status for loadbalancer, listener and pool

Change-Id: I2e35431216c80d39810659cdb1d872e0bd3a3066

added_lines: # Copyright 2015 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import testscenarios from neutron_lbaas.tests.tempest.v2.api import base from tempest.common.utils import data_utils from tempest import config from tempest.openstack.common import log as logging from tempest import test CONF = config.CONF LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) scenario1 = ('lb-T-lis-T-pool-T', {'lb_value': True, 'listener_value': True, 'pool_value': True}) scenario2 = ('lb-T-lis-T-pool-F', {'lb_value': True, 'listener_value': True, 'pool_value': False}) scenario3 = ('lb-T-lis-F-pool-T', {'lb_value': True, 'listener_value': False, 'pool_value': True}) scenario4 = ('lb-T-lis-F-pool-F', {'lb_value': True, 'listener_value': False, 'pool_value': False}) scenario5 = ('lb-F-lis-T-pool-T', {'lb_value': False, 'listener_value': True, 'pool_value': True}) scenario6 = ('lb-F-lis-T-pool-F', {'lb_value': False, 'listener_value': True, 'pool_value': False}) scenario7 = ('lb-F-lis-F-pool-T', {'lb_value': False, 'listener_value': False, 'pool_value': True}) scenario8 = ('lb-F-lis-F-pool-F', {'lb_value': False, 'listener_value': False, 'pool_value': False}) class PoolAdminStateTests(testscenarios.TestWithScenarios, base.BaseTestCase): scenarios = [scenario1, scenario2, scenario3, scenario4, scenario5, scenario6, scenario7, scenario8] """ Tests the following operations in the Neutron-LBaaS API using the REST client for Pools: create pool with different scenarios update pool admin_state_up as True with different scenarios update pool admin_state_up as False with different scenarios """ @classmethod def resource_setup(cls): super(PoolAdminStateTests, cls).resource_setup() if not test.is_extension_enabled('lbaas', 'network'): msg = "lbaas extension not enabled." raise cls.skipException(msg) network_name = data_utils.rand_name('network-') cls.network = cls.create_network(network_name) cls.subnet = cls.create_subnet(cls.network) cls.create_lb_kwargs = {'tenant_id': cls.subnet['tenant_id'], 'vip_subnet_id': cls.subnet['id']} cls.protocol = 'HTTP' cls.port = 8081 cls.create_listener_kwargs = {'protocol': cls.protocol, 'protocol_port': cls.port} cls.lb_algorithm = 'ROUND_ROBIN' cls.create_pools_kwargs = {'protocol': cls.protocol, 'lb_algorithm': cls.lb_algorithm} @classmethod def resource_cleanup(cls): super(PoolAdminStateTests, cls).resource_cleanup() @classmethod def setup_load_balancer(cls, **kwargs): new_load_balancer = cls._create_active_load_balancer( **kwargs) new_load_balancer_id = new_load_balancer['id'] cls.load_balancer = cls.load_balancers_client.get_load_balancer( new_load_balancer_id) def operating_status_validation(self, load_balancer, listeners, pools): if self.lb_value is False: # validating operating status for loadbalancer, listener, pool self.assertEqual("DISABLED", load_balancer['operating_status']) self.assertEqual(listeners[0]['operating_status'], 'DISABLED') self.assertEqual(pools[0]['operating_status'], 'DISABLED') else: self.assertEqual("ONLINE", load_balancer['operating_status']) if self.listener_value is False: # validating operating status for listener self.assertEqual(listeners[0]['operating_status'], 'DISABLED') else: self.assertEqual(listeners[0]['operating_status'], 'ONLINE') if self.pool_value is False: # validating operating status for pool self.assertEqual(pools[0]['operating_status'], 'DISABLED') else: self.assertEqual(pools[0]['operating_status'], 'ONLINE') def test_create_pool_with_admin_state_scenarios(self): """ Test create pool with different scenarios of admin_state_up field for loadbalancer, listener and pool """ self.create_lb_kwargs['admin_state_up'] = self.lb_value self.setup_load_balancer(**self.create_lb_kwargs) self.new_load_balancer_id = self.load_balancer.get('id') self.create_listener_kwargs['admin_state_up'] = self.listener_value self.create_listener_kwargs['loadbalancer_id'] = ( self.new_load_balancer_id) new_listener = self._create_listener(**self.create_listener_kwargs) self.new_listener_id = new_listener['id'] self.listener = self.listeners_client.get_listener( self.new_listener_id) self.create_pools_kwargs['admin_state_up'] = self.pool_value self.create_pools_kwargs['listener_id'] = self.new_listener_id new_pool = self._create_pool(**self.create_pools_kwargs) self.new_pool_id = new_pool['id'] self.pool = self.pools_client.get_pool(self.new_pool_id) statuses = (self.load_balancers_client.get_load_balancer_status_tree (self.new_load_balancer_id)) load_balancer = statuses['loadbalancer'] listeners = load_balancer['listeners'] pools = load_balancer['listeners'][0]['pools'] self.operating_status_validation(load_balancer, listeners, pools) self._delete_pool(self.new_pool_id) self._delete_listener(self.new_listener_id) self._delete_load_balancer(self.new_load_balancer_id) def test_update_pool_with_admin_state_up_true_scenarios(self): """ Test update pool with different scenarios of admin_state_up field for loadbalancer, listener and specifying pool's as true """ self.create_lb_kwargs['admin_state_up'] = self.lb_value self.setup_load_balancer(**self.create_lb_kwargs) self.new_load_balancer_id = self.load_balancer.get('id') self.create_listener_kwargs['admin_state_up'] = self.listener_value self.create_listener_kwargs['loadbalancer_id'] = ( self.new_load_balancer_id) new_listener = self._create_listener(**self.create_listener_kwargs) self.new_listener_id = new_listener['id'] self.listener = self.listeners_client.get_listener( self.new_listener_id) self.create_pools_kwargs['admin_state_up'] = True self.create_pools_kwargs['listener_id'] = self.new_listener_id new_pool = self._create_pool(**self.create_pools_kwargs) self.new_pool_id = new_pool['id'] self.pool = self.pools_client.get_pool(self.new_pool_id) self._update_pool(self.new_pool_id, admin_state_up=self.pool_value) self.pool = self.pools_client.get_pool(self.new_pool_id) statuses = ( self.load_balancers_client.get_load_balancer_status_tree (self.new_load_balancer_id)) load_balancer = statuses['loadbalancer'] listeners = load_balancer['listeners'] pools = load_balancer['listeners'][0]['pools'] self.operating_status_validation(load_balancer, listeners, pools) self._delete_pool(self.new_pool_id) self._delete_listener(self.new_listener_id) self._delete_load_balancer(self.new_load_balancer_id) def test_update_pool_with_admin_state_up_false_scenarios(self): """ Test update pool with different scenarios of admin_state_up field for loadbalancer, listener and specifying pool as false """ self.create_lb_kwargs['admin_state_up'] = self.lb_value self.setup_load_balancer(**self.create_lb_kwargs) self.new_load_balancer_id = self.load_balancer.get('id') self.create_listener_kwargs['admin_state_up'] = self.listener_value self.create_listener_kwargs['loadbalancer_id'] = ( self.new_load_balancer_id) new_listener = self._create_listener(**self.create_listener_kwargs) self.new_listener_id = new_listener['id'] self.listener = self.listeners_client.get_listener( self.new_listener_id) self.create_pools_kwargs['admin_state_up'] = False self.create_pools_kwargs['listener_id'] = self.new_listener_id new_pool = self._create_pool(**self.create_pools_kwargs) self.new_pool_id = new_pool['id'] self.pool = self.pools_client.get_pool(self.new_pool_id) self._update_pool(self.new_pool_id, admin_state_up=self.pool_value) self.pool = self.pools_client.get_pool(self.new_pool_id) statuses = (self.load_balancers_client.get_load_balancer_status_tree (self.new_load_balancer_id)) load_balancer = statuses['loadbalancer'] listeners = load_balancer['listeners'] pools = load_balancer['listeners'][0]['pools'] self.operating_status_validation(load_balancer, listeners, pools) self._delete_pool(self.new_pool_id) self._delete_listener(self.new_listener_id) self._delete_load_balancer(self.new_load_balancer_id)

commit_message:
Remove ceilometer vars present in group_vars

There is no need to redefine these vars at the playbook
level when they are already defined in the group_vars for
the all group.

Change-Id: I4ef48b5cd34f5c751bf927fce4c9ffa9bd590992

commit_message:
Split Heat pacemaker roles into separate services

In order for each service to operate independently when used with Pacemaker,
the roles needed to be separated.

This also drops all pacemaker constraints, as they do not make much sense
in the composable realm.

Change-Id: I3fa76562c13191884a53848ad5adcbc9f5a24f61

subject: Update overcloud dns servers
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-05 10:10:56.000000000', 'files': ['roles/tripleo/undercloud/defaults/main.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart/commit/57de62e9e7ebddabfca6aae2e9407af7cc5f14ab', 'message': 'Update overcloud dns servers

They were pointing to google, so they were not operative.
It was also causing slowness when connecting via ssh, because
it was trying to resolve undercloud address, and nameservers
were not responding.

Switch to use external network gateway, by this way ssh is
fast and instances can resolve properly.

Change-Id: I8a03e07f259fd92a4219f6d65e47e07044657945
Closes-Bug: 1598722
'}]
commit_message:
Update overcloud dns servers

They were pointing to google, so they were not operative.
It was also causing slowness when connecting via ssh, because
it was trying to resolve undercloud address, and nameservers
were not responding.

Switch to use external network gateway, by this way ssh is
fast and instances can resolve properly.

Change-Id: I8a03e07f259fd92a4219f6d65e47e07044657945
Closes-Bug: 1598722
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart refs/changes/88/337588/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: DnsServers: [ '{{ external_network_cidr|nthhost(1) }}' ]

commit_message:
Make virt pool creation more robust and less susceptible to failures

See https://www.redhat.com/archives/libvirt-users/2016-March/msg00123.html
See https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo-quickstart/+bug/1577809
We continue to hit this issue even w/ the current clean up.  This additional

* remove any remaining virt pool information from previous installs in /run/user
* before creating the pool test for it's existence.

Note: need to have Lars review this patch.

Change-Id: I0eda9d169103d30e8d5ef6fba9e146cd3d0a4cc9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart refs/changes/72/337772/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Tempest API tests using testscenarios for create/update loadbalancer

Introducing tempest data-driven scenario tests for validating attributes when:

(a) create loadbalancer with:
    (i) admin_state_up as True
    (ii) admin_state_up as False

(b) update loadbalancer with:
    (i) update lb when default admin_state_up is true
    (ii) update lb when default admin_state_up is false

Change-Id: I39ec1754967bc56ecc0cf1633f21773c544289b5
Co-Authored-By: Franklin Naval  <franklin.naval@RACKSPACE.COM>

commit_message:
run_tests: checkout tempest from master on Ubuntu

On Ubuntu, come back to Tempest master.
So we have to disable Sahara and Neutron FWaaS now, as we need more
recent packaging in UCA, that will be provided after N2.

Change-Id: Ib3f9e368628389819540e2575762c7c302dc05d8

Change-Id: Idcfc6ea26ca41534ce407be0eb3dafe7bcd2ef2d

commit_message:
pacemaker: don't override Service resource for Nova & Neutron

Nova & Neutron services are already managed by puppet-tripleo in
profiles, and we already override Service resource for some services to
manage them with Pacemaker.
Dropping this code here will allow us to run TripleO in AIO setup as we
don't manage everything with Pacemaker.

Change-Id: Idcfc6ea26ca41534ce407be0eb3dafe7bcd2ef2d

commit_message:
Added federation support for OpenID Connect with mod_auth_openidc

Change-Id: I710de4f38b899ab04cec8b3c5188e8a383bec18c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-keystone refs/changes/42/333742/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: LoadModule auth_openidc_module modules/mod_auth_openidc.so WSGIScriptAliasMatch ^(/v3/OS-FEDERATION/identity_providers/.*?/protocols/.*?/auth)$ <%= scope['keystone::params::keystone_wsgi_script_path'] -%>/$1 OIDCClaimPrefix "OIDC-" OIDCResponseType "id_token" OIDCScope "openid email profile" OIDCProviderMetadataURL "<%= scope['keystone::federation::openidc::openidc_provider_metadata_url']-%>" OIDCClientID "<%= scope['keystone::federation::openidc::openidc_client_id']-%>" OIDCClientSecret "<%= scope['keystone::federation::openidc::openidc_client_secret']-%>" OIDCCryptoPassphrase "<%= scope['keystone::federation::openidc::openidc_crypto_passphrase']-%>" OIDCRedirectURI "<%= scope['keystone::federation::openidc::openidc_redirect_uri']-%>" <Location /v3/auth/OS-FEDERATION/identity_providers/<%= scope['keystone::federation::openidc::idp_name']-%>/protocols/openidc/auth> AuthType "openid-connect" Require valid-user </Location>

commit_message:
Rework os check

This change updates the way we do the os check to use the
os facts rather than running facter via beaker.

Change-Id: Iaee0ad6252b44ad2e2b5e6478957084c5aa18c05
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack_extras refs/changes/65/335665/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # hack because BKR-821, so facter isn't found when running beaker. osfamily = fact 'osfamily' if osfamily == 'RedHat' else expect(shell('apt-get install -y python-openstackclient').exit_code).to be_zero expect(shell('apt-cache policy python-openstackclient | grep -A 1 \*\*\*').stdout).to match(/#{release}/)
deleted_lines: case fact('osfamily') when 'Debian' expect(shell('apt-get install -y python-openstackclient').exit_code).to be_zero expect(shell('apt-cache policy python-openstackclient | grep -A 1 \*\*\*').stdout).to match(/#{release}/) when 'Redhat'

commit_message:
Add misssing parameters to keystone_authtoken

Added keystonemiddleware parameters according to [1]
Remove deprecated parameters instead of deprecate them,
since this define is not used yet.

Keystonemiddleware documentation:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/keystonemiddleware/middlewarearchitecture.html#configuration

add release note

Co-Authored-By: Iury Gregory <iurygregory@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-23 14:38:09.000000000', 'files': ['oslo_versionedobjects/fixture.py', 'oslo_versionedobjects/tests/test_fixture.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.versionedobjects/commit/cf281254478065a487fe502e52c1b3369f24f0ef', 'message': 'Extend test_hashes to allow extra info gathering

ObjectVersionChecker.get_hashes() already support extra data collection
for fingerprint generation via the extra_data_func parameter.
However this cannot be used from test_hashes().

Nova versioned notification work depends on this extra data gathering

Change-Id: I7f4d0f37e638de6fcef7211280cedd7d1f09ab74

commit_message:
Extend test_hashes to allow extra info gathering

ObjectVersionChecker.get_hashes() already support extra data collection
for fingerprint generation via the extra_data_func parameter.
However this cannot be used from test_hashes().

Nova versioned notification work depends on this extra data gathering
support. See nova bug #1595575

Change-Id: I7f4d0f37e638de6fcef7211280cedd7d1f09ab74
Closes-Bug: #1595552
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.versionedobjects refs/changes/82/333382/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_test_hashes_passes_extra_func(self): # Make sure that test_hashes passes the extra_func to get_hashes mock_extra_func = mock.Mock() with mock.patch.object(self.ovc, 'get_hashes') as mock_get_hashes: self.ovc.test_hashes({}, extra_data_func=mock_extra_func) mock_get_hashes.assert_called_once_with( extra_data_func=mock_extra_func)

commit_message:
Add string checking param to LBaaSv2 healthmonitor

Neutron LBaaSv2 healthmonitor allows validation of the HTTP return code within
the member reply.
Loadbalancers allow an addional validation, where the existence of a string
within the member response determines the member health status.
This patch adds the necessary param for the validation above.

Change-Id: Ie6b58a4f885fb0906b342696675005a23c7cdb60
Fixes-Bug: #1523231

commit_message:
Make note template follow correct formatting

The template used to create a new release note does not follow the ReST
standards[0]. This can be confusing to a contributor who may be
unfamiliar with the formatting requirements, as they will tend to follow
the template format, and end up with incorrect ReST. This patch adds the
required vertical bar and newline to each section.

[0] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/reno/usage.html#formatting

Change-Id: Ie8cbe524376a3c3e1e11446abdc6e5fa00233d51

Have import order follow standard and fix misspelling

Have the import order follow the OpenStack standard:
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#import-order-template

Basically the reno imports should be the final section of imports.

Fix a misspelled word.

commit_message:
Disable libvirt tunnelled migrations

Selective live block migration between compute instances
is only supported if libvirt tunnelled migrations are
disabled; migration is still secure (over SSH).

This allows instances with local ephemeral storage and
remote block devices (such as presented by ceph) to be
migrated.

Closes-Bug: 1599205

Change-Id: I1560e11bac9ee5dabb8d6b6e393a31a2f3c9aa74
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-nova-compute refs/changes/32/337732/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Disable tunnelled migration so that selective # live block migration can be supported. live_migration_tunnelled = False

commit_message:
JSON schema get_schema implementation for common fields

This implements the get_schema method of common Field and FieldType classes.
This method will be used by the to_json_schema method in Versioned objects
to partially generate the schema of the object's fields.
Fields implemented in this patch: string, enum, integer, float, boolean, list

This also fixes check for default value for Field.

Implements blueprint json-schema-for-versioned-object

Change-Id: Ibd84cb4e33c375044611c6ffa137ee67d21a93e5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.versionedobjects refs/changes/56/328356/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_schema(self): return {'type': ['string']} def get_schema(self): return {'enum': [self.stringify(val) for val in self.valid_values]} def get_schema(self): return {'type': ['integer']} def get_schema(self): return {'type': ['number']} def get_schema(self): return {'type': ['boolean']} def get_schema(self): return {'type': ['array'], 'items': self._element_type.get_schema()}

commit_message:
Add new posix element.

This element installs package to ensure that the resulting image
provides the binaries outlined in posix specification [1]. This solves
some problems such as cron missing from the ubuntu-minimal images, and
hopefully minimizing the problems from similar problems in the future.

This is the image size difference:

Resulting qcow image sizes:

                Ubuntu      Ubuntu-Minimal    Debian    Centos7
        None    334MB       330MB             352MB     470MB
        Posix   353MB       375MB
        Posix+  354MB       374MB             406MB     471MB

        Posix+ = Posix + gcc + cssc

[1] http://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/idx/utilities.html

Change-Id: I2a8f77bf8a0fdb04b328e56425d43a60eb3f7eed

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-30 18:19:50.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/agent/linux/iptables_firewall.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/agent/linux/test_iptables_firewall.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/470d046e91d16204ef64237d89b817c87307b696', 'message': "De-dup user-defined SG rules before iptables call

commit_message:
De-dup user-defined SG rules before iptables call

A port may be a member of multiple security groups. These
security groups may have dupilcate rules between them
(e.g. they both allow all EGRESS traffic). If the iptables
manager is called with duplicated rules, it emits a warning
of a possible bug in the rule generation code because it
doesn't expect there to be duplicated rules.

This patch fixes this by de-duplicating user-defined security group
rules before dispatching the calls to the iptables_manager.

Change-Id: I98dbe60df1bcf68b9922deee63dd0328c4c10dd0
Closes-Bug: #1565705
(cherry picked from commit 142b68f0757ab036d56bc9b4563b7a4481527deb)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/52/336152/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_user_sg_rules_deduped_before_call_to_iptables_manager(self): port = self._fake_port() port['security_group_rules'] = [{'ethertype': 'IPv4', 'direction': 'ingress'}] * 2 self.firewall.prepare_port_filter(port) rules = [''.join(c[1]) for c in self.v4filter_inst.add_rule.mock_calls] self.assertEqual(len(set(rules)), len(rules))

subject: Add TripleO 2-node job

Adds a new CI job in the experimental-tripleo queue using multinode
nodepool jobs. The job uses 2 subnodes to deploy via TripleO. The
jenkins slave is purposed as the undercloud, and from the 2 subnodes,
one is used as a controller, and the other as a compute.

The job also relies on a newly added custom image,
tripleo-centos-7-overcloud-full. While the custom image is not
technically required, it will save a lot of time if there is an image
already available to use with all the packages pre-installed and built
from the correct set of dib elements.

Without the custom image, we could run a script during the CI job to
apply the needed changes to the standard centos-7 nodepool image.

Change-Id: I8375a96a4f4394b0a0d233731f7f4b386c0d5c71

commit_message:
Add TripleO 2-node job

Adds a new CI job in the experimental-tripleo queue using multinode
nodepool jobs. The job uses 1 subnode to deploy via TripleO. The
jenkins slave is purposed as the undercloud, and an all in one Overcloud
is deployed on the subnode.

Note that support for multinode jobs is being added to tripleo-ci in this
patch: Icc67a289df207348536c0a2419b3fc81f03fe758

Change-Id: I8375a96a4f4394b0a0d233731f7f4b386c0d5c71

subject: pickle_async_update should create tmp_dir
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-16 08:15:05.000000000', 'files': ['test/unit/obj/test_diskfile.py', 'swift/obj/diskfile.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/da4a59f8e276e80764b58f9c52d6a3c2bca06782', 'message': 'pickle_async_update should create tmp_dir

While creating a probe test for the expirer daemon, I found
the following error scenario:

1. Introduce a new object server. Initially it doesn't have a tmp_dir.
2. Have the object-replicator replicate some objects, one of them
    with an expiration (X-Delete-At).
3. Send a DELETE request for the expired object.

While beginning to process the DELETE request, the fresh
object server still doesn't have a tmp_dir created.
Since the object has an old expiration value, the object server
will first call "delete_at_update", before creating a tombstone.
delete_at_update then must create an async_pending,
which will lead to an IO error, since tmp_dir doesn't exist.

As said, I have witnessed this in practice in the probe test I wrote
at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/326903/.

This patch changes pickle_async_update behavior to create
tmp_dir, in case it doesn't exist.

Change-Id: I88b0e5f75a2a28d6880694ff327ac2763c816d24
'}]
commit_message:
pickle_async_update should create tmp_dir

While creating a probe test for the expirer daemon, I found
the following error scenario:

1. Introduce a new object server. Initially it doesn't have a tmp_dir.
2. Have the object-replicator replicate some objects, one of them
    with an expiration (X-Delete-At).
3. Send a DELETE request for the expired object.

While beginning to process the DELETE request, the fresh
object server still doesn't have a tmp_dir created.
Since the object has an old expiration value, the object server
will first call "delete_at_update", before creating a tombstone.
delete_at_update then must create an async_pending,
which will lead to an IO error, since tmp_dir doesn't exist.

As said, I have witnessed this in practice in the probe test I wrote
at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/326903/.

This patch changes pickle_async_update behavior to create
tmp_dir, in case it doesn't exist.

Change-Id: I88b0e5f75a2a28d6880694ff327ac2763c816d24
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/63/330363/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: tmp_dir = os.path.join(device_path, get_tmp_dir(policy)) mkdirs(tmp_dir) tmp_dir)

subject: create_router: Report the original exception
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-01 10:12:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/b7c2501fc7c2b8f8e6027afd00a396cfc97d782d', 'message': "create_router: Handle the case with a surrounding transaction

Some of plugins call us within a transaction.
If _update_router_gw_info breaks the transaction,
and delete_router attempted to start a subtransation,
delete_router ends up with InvalidRequestError.
In that case, just ignore the exception, as we don't need to
revert create_router manually.

Closes-Bug: #1490917
Change-Id: I1cef944115c1911d4b7e60fb4dff389b1911ddbb
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-09-02 06:57:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/994a2a6bf87d161545f59aa1c1b3d958b0985298', 'message': 'create_router: Handle the case with a surrounding transaction

Some of plugins call us within a transaction.
If _update_router_gw_info broke the transaction,
and delete_router attempted to start a subtransation,
delete_router ends up with InvalidRequestError.
Use a nested transaction to avoid breaking the transaction.

Closes-Bug: #1490917
Change-Id: I1cef944115c1911d4b7e60fb4dff389b1911ddbb
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-09-03 11:33:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/ed49c84913a1f2d2961fe3ae03c1fb73aeabf691', 'message': 'create_router: Handle the case with a surrounding transaction

commit_message:
create_router: Report the original exception

In case delete_router, which is an attempt to revert
the operation, failed, report the original exception
rather than the one from delete_router.  The former is
more likely useful for users.  Besides that, it's critical
to preserve the original exception for special exceptions
like RetryRequest.

Also, add some relevant unit tests.

Closes-Bug: #1490917
Change-Id: I1cef944115c1911d4b7e60fb4dff389b1911ddbb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/15/219215/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from sqlalchemy import exc as db_exc try: self.delete_router(context, router_db.id) except db_exc.InvalidRequestError: # NOTE(yamamoto): Some of plugins call us within # a transaction. If _update_router_gw_info breaks # the transaction, and delete_router attempted to # start a subtransation, it ends up with # InvalidRequestError here. In that case, we don't # need to revert create_router manually. pass

commit_message:
Ensure the OVS bridge exists when plugging

When a vif will be plugged into an OVS bridge, ensure that the bridge
exists during the plugging operation. In most cases, the OVS bridge will
already exist at the time of port creation, so this will be a no-op.
However, the OVS agent implementation for vlan-aware VMs will require
the os-vif plugin to create the OVS bridge if it doesn't already exist,
because vifs that correspond to trunk ports won't be directly plugged
into br-int.

Change-Id: I3cb61a5e842177a26f38c85d7782ecced4ac07da
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-vif refs/changes/18/330818/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cmd = _create_ovs_bridge_cmd(bridge) cmd += ['--', '--if-exists', 'del-port', dev, '--',def _create_ovs_bridge_cmd(bridge): return ['--', '--may-exist', 'add-br', bridge] def ensure_ovs_bridge(bridge): _ovs_vsctl(_create_ovs_bridge_cmd(bridge)) @privsep.vif_plug.entrypoint

When the service token is specified auth_token middleware should trust

Change-Id: I64296016757f15632651f9a99f0118318f698ff3

commit_message:
Service user permissions

When the service token is specified auth_token middleware should trust
the headers it receives in the most recent request rather than
validating the user token again.

Change-Id: I64296016757f15632651f9a99f0118318f698ff3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/66/317266/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================= Allow service to provide user permissions ========================================= `bp service-user-permissions <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/service-user-permissions>`_ Since the services split OpenStack has had a problem with long running operations that reuse the user token timing out. An example of this is nova initially validating a user token successfully, then it requests an image from glance however in the mean time the token has expired and so glance rejects the token. This causes very hard to debug timeouts and has resulted in services doing operations as the service user instead of the user so that it can refresh the token. Instead of this we should move to the pattern that a user token is validated only on entry to the OpenStack services and from there in if a service passes user information to another service we should just trust that data is accurate. Problem Description =================== OpenStack services only communicate with each other over the public REST APIs that regular users have access to. A side effect of this is when you do service to service communication it goes through the same token authentication process regardless of whether the user has previously been validated by another service. Because keystone tokens are bearer tokens the easiest way to accomplish this continuous user authentication was to have the service reuse the same token when communicating with others. This works most of the time, however there is an edge case that if the token expiry period is crossed between when the user submits a token and the service passes the token on then token authentication will fail. At scale this edge case becomes a serious problem and is a negative experience for users because the operation may have been running a significant time before failure occurs. It also presents a difficult rollback operation for services because initial service to service requests may succeed which then cannot be rolled back with the expired token. Proposed Change =============== Users should be validated only on entry to the OpenStack ecosystem. This means that when one service is communicating with another service the token data and expiry should not be rechecked. Auth_token middleware currently passes token data information down to the service it protects by inserting additional headers into the request. To ensure that there is no abuse currently it makes sure to unset any of the headers it may use before beginning validation so that extra data can never make it to the user. There is an existing rarely used concept in auth_token middleware of the X-Service-Token. The X-Service-Token is a token created by the service that issued the request. When a request is received with an X-Service-Token header this token is also validate and it's information passed to the service which allows the service to enforce joint ownership and other permissions on the operation. For example in swift, an object was created for a user but created by the nova service. Policy should be able to enforce that the object can only be deleted via combination of the nova service user and the user token. We can utilize the X-Service-Token concept to ensure that a request originated from another service and not directly from a user. Alternatives ------------ There are a number of alternatives that have been discussed in the past: Nothing +++++++ Today OpenStack is able to function with the current limitations but more and more services are doing workarounds to prevent token timeouts. Typically this involves setting up a short term trust from a user to the service that is performing the operation. This doesn't solve the problem in an inter-service manner and increases the dependence on keystone to setup and revoke these trusts. Also, in the event that every service adopts this pattern we have the situation where a new trust is created for each level of service the token passes through. It is a common complaint from services that we should look at fixing properly. Delegation ++++++++++ Ideally the correct way to solve these problems is to epxlicitly delegate to each service a user communicates with. With this addition we could remove the bearer token problem entirely. This is deemed an impossible change to make at this point. It would require massively changing how all services communicate and in most delegation mechanisms would require each service to maintain its own user information and delegation tables. In the event that we do an OpenStack 2 we should come up with a proper delegation story to the services from the start that doesn't involve bearer tokens. Don't check token expiry ++++++++++++++++++++++++ A variation of this proposal is when passing the X-Auth-Token and X-Service-Token we don't check the expiry of the X-Auth-Token. The problem with this is it would require keystone being able to reconstruct an expired token. This is a significant change to the API for token validation, but also in the case of UUID tokens this data may no longer be available. To make this work we would need to change the persistence mechanisms and impose time windows on how long a token must be available after it has expired. This would likely cause problems with operators cleanup. Reconstruct a token from basic data +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ Rather than trust everything that a service passes we could pass the core token data between services and have keystone confirm the token data when validating the service token. This would look similar to a fernet token reconstruction in that we could determine all token information from a few core parameters like user_id and project_id. This in my opinion is the most reasonable alternative as a service would be unable to pass invalid information to another service. It would requiring adding a new API to keystone that is capable of constructing this token data that is protected by policy to only be accessible to the service users. Ideally for performance we could roll this into one API that is capable of validating the service and the user token in one call rather than doing two calls for every validation. The question at this point becomes how far do we trust our services? The information available from this token reconstruction would be the same as the information that the last service possessed and could have forwarded, so we are preventing the possibility that a service itself is maliciously sending incorrect data. However we are only limiting that it send invalid incorrect data, even with this alternative we cannot prevent that a service send a valid user and project combination. By adopting this proposal at all we are transferring a certain amount of trust on to the services, so at what point do we draw the line on trusting the information they provide? We would still need to provide an auth plugin for services that handles sending this core auth data. As proven by fernet tokens these core auth parameters that cannot be reconstructed keep growing. Security Impact --------------- This blueprint represents a fundamental change in how OpenStack validates tokens and so has many security implications. The primary concern is the level of trust we are placing on the services. With a valid service token we are explicitly trusting (not validating via keystone) all of the user information that is passed. This means that someone possessing a service token is capable of issuing any request on behalf of any user regardless of this being a valid keystone relation. It would also be capable of for example adding roles to a user's information before passing it on. This escalates the privileges of a service to nearly that of an admin as it can emulate any request. Notifications Impact -------------------- None. Other End User Impact --------------------- None. This change should be completely transparent to an end user. Performance Impact ------------------ This will have a small boost in performance for services that are already utilizing the X-Service-Token because they are currently doing two individual token validations, one for the user token and one for the service token. This will reduce to only one validation call. Ideally we will reduce the requirements of some services that currently set up a trust for long running operations to prevent the timeout issue. There is some concern about the amount of data passed over the RPC bus, however in practice it seems that all this information is already present just inconsistently named between services. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- We will require a new option added to the auth_token middleware options that validate that the X-Service-Token has a role capable of bypassing the user token validation step. This could be implemented simply by adding a config option specifying a required role or by implementing some level of oslo.policy support in auth_token middleware. Developer Impact ---------------- It is unfeasible to expect developers of the individual services to know and keep current with all the headers that are passed from auth_token middleware and that should therefore be sent from service to service. We will therefore need to create a keystoneauth plugin that is capable of adding the headers and being updated without customizing the services individually. This will be easier in some services than others but we will need to update those services so that they correctly use this plugin. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: jamielennox Other contributors: Work Items ---------- * The X-Service-Token is validated by auth_token middleware but it is not currently asserted that the service token actually came from another service. If a user pass the X-Service-Token header this would also be validated. If we intend to bypass the user token validation process this is unacceptable and we must verify that the token passed as the X-Service-Token is allowed to invoke this bypass. Because there is no keystone server changes to this blueprint we cannot enforce this via policy in keystone so we will need to add a policy check on the X-Service-Token to auth_token via configuration. * Change to auth_token middleware so that if the service token is validated and a minimal set of the authentication headers are present in the request that we skip directly validating the user token (if present). * Addition to oslo.context, keystoneauth or some other location to create an auth plugin that is capable of sending all the required authentication headers along with a request. * Start making other service use the above plugin for service to service communication rather than the custom mechanisms they currently have. Dependencies ============ * Involved in this is going to be a lot of standardization of oslo.context and oslo.messaging to involve that we can pass the correct authentication information between services and between service components so that the correct headers are sent and can be modified as new headers are added without explicitly having to go to each of the services and change them individually. Documentation Impact ==================== The change in token validation logic should be documented as this is a change that deployers should understand. References ========== * `X-Service-Token Specification <https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/keystone-specs/specs/keystonemiddleware/juno/service-tokens.html>`_.

commit_message:
Fix VPNaaS functional tests

Change Ie27cf174fa24c2f479af47335d9ae139fb7d159a broke functional
testing by changing the location and name of MySQLTestCase and
PostgresSQLTestCase.  Point code to the new name and location.

Side effect, all TestIPSecScenario tests have been decorated to
be skipped because of bug 1598466 to allow this patch to merge
reliably.

subject: Add __ne__ built-in function
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-05 05:30:56.000000000', 'files': ['tests/unit/utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-swiftclient/commit/f4f2e6c261b62698eb31e2fc78a2777e54b72594', 'message': 'Add __ne__ built-in function

In Python 3 __ne__ by default delegates to __eq__ and inverts the
result, but in Python 2 they urge you to define __ne__ when you
define __eq__ for it to work properly [1].There are no implied
relationships among the comparison operators. The truth of x==y
does not imply that x!=y is false. Accordingly, when defining
__eq__(), one should also define __ne__() so that the operators
will behave as expected.
[1]https://docs.python.org/2/reference/datamodel.html#object.__ne__

Change-Id: I5485022f010cdcb88c0d4ebe5c44a39a1bf242b0
'}]
commit_message:
Add __ne__ built-in function

In Python 3 __ne__ by default delegates to __eq__ and inverts the
result, but in Python 2 they urge you to define __ne__ when you
define __eq__ for it to work properly [1].There are no implied
relationships among the comparison operators. The truth of x==y
does not imply that x!=y is false. Accordingly, when defining
__eq__(), one should also define __ne__() so that the operators
will behave as expected.
[1]https://docs.python.org/2/reference/datamodel.html#object.__ne__

Change-Id: I5485022f010cdcb88c0d4ebe5c44a39a1bf242b0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-swiftclient refs/changes/27/337427/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __ne__(self, other): return not self.__eq__(other)

commit_message:
[WiP] Add tempest tests for static actions API

Change-Id: I04c7d83d430dd73a01915878954b6ff957976277
Targets: blueprint static-actions
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/52/337652/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2016 Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import os import testtools from tempest import config from murano_tempest_tests.tests.api.application_catalog import base from murano_tempest_tests import utils CONF = config.CONF class TestStaticActions(base.BaseApplicationCatalogTest): @classmethod def resource_setup(cls): if CONF.application_catalog.glare_backend: msg = ("Murano using GLARE backend. " "Static actions tests will be skipped.") raise cls.skipException(msg) super(TestStaticActions, cls).resource_setup() application_name = utils.generate_name('test_repository_class') cls.abs_archive_path, dir_with_archive, archive_name = \ utils.prepare_package( application_name, app='io.murano.apps.test.ExampleStaticAction', create_manifest=False) cls.package = cls.application_catalog_client.upload_package( application_name, archive_name, dir_with_archive, {"categories": [], "tags": [], 'is_public': False}) @classmethod def resource_cleanup(cls): super(TestStaticActions, cls).resource_cleanup() os.remove(cls.abs_archive_path) cls.application_catalog_client.delete_package(cls.package['id']) @testtools.testcase.attr('smoke') def test_call_static_action_basic(self): action_result = self.application_catalog_client.call_static_action( 'io.murano.apps.test.ExampleStaticAction', 'staticAction', args={'myName': 'John'}) self.assertEqual('Hello, John', action_result) @testtools.testcase.attr('smoke') def test_call_static_action_full(self): action_result = self.application_catalog_client.call_static_action( 'io.murano.apps.test.ExampleStaticAction', 'staticAction', package_name='io.murano.apps.test.ExampleStaticAction', class_version="<1", args={'myName': 'John'}) self.assertEqual('Hello, John', action_result)

commit_message:
VMware: create vif with resource limitations

Change Id321ffcb17114b53141f2489156869d418b768fd allows to
create instance with vif having resource limitations.

This patch adds ability to derive the network resource
allocation (quota:vif_reservation, quota:vif_limit,
quota:vif_shares_level, quota:vif_shares_share) from
flavor extra specs while attaching new interfaces to an instance.

Implements: blueprint vmware-limits-newton

Change-Id: Ib090ac3d1e007ab33a2ff5ff37f731e40c113621

commit_message:
Make plugin collection time warning value configurable

Allow the value of sub_collection_warn to be configurable using
monasca_setup. However, use the name plugin_collect_time_warn
as the configuration option since that is easier to understand

Change-Id: I769ec9dd1dcfb1fba5a6da9b59cf03376707c4a6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/49/335249/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: parser.add_argument('--plugin_collect_time_warn', help="Number of seconds a plugin collection time exceeds " + "that causes a warning to be logged for that plugin", type=validate_positive, default=6)

commit_message:
Use NO_MONITOR status for member creation

When adding a member to a pool that does not have an active health
monitor, utilize the NO_MONITOR status.  This will remove confusion around
the true operating status of the member.

Change-Id: Id5ba7e982f7159fbcf1100a011aa81b1b1b3757e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas refs/changes/64/320664/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ), cfg.BoolOpt( 'use_no_monitor_status', default=False, help=_('True if Octavia will use the NO_MONITOR status for a member on' ' a pool with no health monitor.') @property def use_no_monitor_status(self): """Does this driver utilize the NO_MONITOR status for a member""" return self.load_balancer.use_no_monitor_status def use_no_monitor_status(self): return cfg.CONF.octavia.use_no_monitor_status @property

commit_message:
Use proper php packages on xenial

Xenial doesn't have php5 packages, update bindep fallback to reflect
this properly and get php packages installed correctly.

Change-Id: Ie05f4cb781f5b9bbfd3a85af23a2e4c966d642ea

commit_message:
Add django-floppyforms, advanced Django Forms extension

This library provides capabilities for advanced rendering of Django Forms.

- Is the library actively maintained?

  Yes:
    https://github.com/gregmuellegger/django-floppyforms/graphs/contributors

- Is the library good code?

  The code is simple, small, mature and covered with tests, under CI.

- Is the library python 3 compatible?

  The library supports versions from 2.6 to 3.5 and PyPy.

- Is the library license compatible?

  The library is BSD licensed.

- Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu
  latest / Fedora latest)?

  Ubuntu 16.X: Not packaged
  Fedora 24: Not packaged

- Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries
  in ``global-requirements.txt``?

  No.

- Is the library required for OpenStack project or related dev or
  infrastructure setup? (Answer to this should be Yes, of course)
  Which?

  This library is required for this change:
    https://review.openstack.org/#/c/175215/

  And this blueprint:
    https://blueprints.launchpad.net/murano/+spec/assign-category-button

Change-Id: Ie65a77eab29aa191420fbd630b1d242b59c9ff9f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/60/337060/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
cloudkitty 0.5.1 for Mitaka

Change-Id: Ia4196161c5432fb81b97b89a32dee5cf6b82c05a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/62/334562/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - version: 0.5.1 projects: - repo: openstack/cloudkitty hash: 669a316d8102746e9848bdeb9cf0ce21fa72e541 highlights: | Bug fixes: - Resources inserted after the sample are now handled by CloudKitty. - Gnocchi resource retrieval is fixed. - Fixed UUID size of gnocchi resource. - Better transformer stability and bug fixes. - Fixed alembic contraint naming. - Fixed problem with ON DELETE field disappearing after migrations on SQLite backends. Improvements: - Better test coverage. - Gabbi API tests on every modules. Impacts: Database migrations need to be run to correct HashMap constraints and Gnocchi UUID size.

commit_message:
Disable rax-iad temporarily

There are networking problems at rax-iad that lead to timeouts of
jobs.

Disable rax-iad for now.

commit_message:
Adjust smoke test to search in examples directory.

The latest puppet recommendation are for examples of working manifest to
be put in the examples directory.  This patch ensure that we first
search this one before moving on the tests directory, for backward
compatibility.

Change-Id: I2699eaa3a10589c9a0c680bb1de489994fe01b67
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstack_spec_helper refs/changes/08/337708/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: smoke_manifest_file = example_file(file) private def example_file(file) smoke_manifest_file = '' found = true ['examples', 'tests'].each do |ex_dir| smoke_dir = File.join(project_root_directory, ex_dir) smoke_manifest_file = File.join(smoke_dir, file.sub(/\.pp$/, '') + '.pp') break if File.exists?(smoke_manifest_file) found = false end unless found raise ArgumentError, "Cannot find smoke manifest file '#{file}' in 'tests' or 'examples' directory" end smoke_manifest_file end
deleted_lines: smoke_dir = File.join(project_root_directory, 'tests') smoke_manifest_file = File.join(smoke_dir, file.sub(/\.pp$/, '') + '.pp') unless File.exists?(smoke_manifest_file) raise ArgumentError, "Cannot find smoke manifest file '#{smoke_manifest_file}'" end

Refactor to source charm

This is in line with the agreed conventions on where to put
files in a layered source package.

Essentially, just the final moving of things around and ensuring
that the dummy tests pass, along with lint.

commit_message:
Allow kubectl to use its own configured endpoint for kube API

Right now, kolla-kubernetes overrides the kube API endpoint by feeding
kubectl the --server option.  We should not do this, which currently
hardcodes to use the localhost:8080 hyperkube endpoint.  This is
unexpected for the operator.  Allow kubectl to use its own configured
endpoint for kube API.

Change-Id: I39db523335126fe77abf3cb089e8f6d3965f76f4

commit_message:
Remove remove_unused_kernels option

The deprecated config option ``remove_unused_kernels`` has been removed
from the ``[libvirt]`` config section. No replacement is required,
as this behaviour is no longer relevant.

Change-Id: I6582cf3c3f1dab1929541d651ce00cef9bef0fbc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/38/337538/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # DEPRECATED # # [*remove_unused_kernels*] # (optional) DEPRECATED. Should unused kernel images be removed? # This is only safe to enable if all compute nodes # have been updated to support this option. # If undef is specified, remove the line in nova.conf # otherwise, use a boolean to remove or not the kernels. # Defaults to undef # # Deprecated $remove_unused_kernels = undef, if $remove_unused_kernels { warning('remove_unused_kernels parameter is deprecated, has no effect and will be removed in a future release.') }

commit_message:
WIP: Neutron-LBaaSv2: Network Topology Tests

* data driven test that checks the cross product
  of the following network topologies for a lb
  and it's associated servers:
  private, public, isolated

Change-Id: I2ca962f04ac130d7063be84dacfd546ee2a47157
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas refs/changes/12/319512/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2016 Rackspace Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import random from tempest.lib.common.utils import data_utils from tempest.lib import exceptions as ex from tempest.scenario import network_resources from tempest import test import testscenarios from neutron_lbaas.tests.tempest.v2.api import base VALID_PORT = data_utils.rand_int_id(1, 65535) INVALID_PORT = random.choice([data_utils.rand_int_id(65535, 99999), data_utils.rand_int_id(-1, 0)]) PUBLIC = 'public' PRIVATE = 'private' ISOLATED = data_utils.rand_name('network-') scenario_network_public_lb = ('lb_public', {'lb_network': PUBLIC}) scenario_network_private_lb = ('lb_private', {'lb_network': PRIVATE}) scenario_network_isolated_lb = ('lb_isolated', {'lb_network': ISOLATED}) scenario_network_public_server = ('server_public', {'server_network': PUBLIC}) scenario_network_private_server = ('server_private', {'server_network': PRIVATE}) scenario_network_isolated_server = ('server_isolated', {'server_network': ISOLATED}) scenario_lb = [scenario_network_public_lb, scenario_network_private_lb, scenario_network_isolated_lb] scenario_server = [scenario_network_public_server, scenario_network_private_server, scenario_network_isolated_server] scenario_lb_server = testscenarios.multiply_scenarios( scenario_lb, scenario_server) class TestNetworkTopology(testscenarios.TestWithScenarios, base.BaseAdminTestCase): """ Tests different network topologies for load balancers using the Neutron-LBaaS API. 3 types of networks: public, private and isolated servers will live on either 3 lb will live on either 3 pretest setup: _get_network_by_name for public and private 1. Create network type. 2. Create load balancer on network type. 3. Verify stuff works. (scnearioize) """ scenarios = scenario_lb_server @classmethod def resource_setup(cls): super(TestNetworkTopology, cls).resource_setup() if not test.is_extension_enabled('lbaas', 'network'): msg = "lbaas extension not enabled." raise cls.skipException(msg) # # cls._get_network_by_name('public') # # # network_name = data_utils.rand_name('network-') # # # cls.network = cls.create_network(network_name) # cls.subnet = cls.create_subnet(cls.network) # cls.subnet_id = cls.subnet.get('id') # cls.tenant_id = cls.subnet.get('tenant_id') # cls.load_balancer = cls._create_load_balancer( # tenant_id=cls.tenant_id, # vip_subnet_id=cls.subnet_id, # wait=True) # cls.load_balancer_id = cls.load_balancer.get('id') @classmethod def resource_cleanup(cls): cls._try_delete_resource(cls._delete_load_balancer, cls.load_balancer.get('id')) cls._wait_for_load_balancer_status( load_balancer_id=cls.load_balancer.get('id'), delete=True) super(TestNetworkTopology, cls).resource_cleanup() def setUp(self): super(TestNetworkTopology, self).setUp() # Setup network for servers if self.server_network is not ISOLATED: self.test_server_network = self._get_network_by_name(self.server_network) subnet = self._list_subnets(network_id=self.test_server_network['id'])[0] self.server_subnet = network_resources.AttributeDict(subnet) else: self.test_server_network = self.create_network(self.server_network) self.server_subnet = self.create_subnet(self.test_server_network) self.server_subnet_id = self.server_subnet.get('id') self.server_tenant_id = self.server_subnet.get('tenant_id') # Setup network for LB if self.lb_network is not ISOLATED: self.test_lb_network = self._get_network_by_name(self.lb_network) subnet = self._list_subnets(network_id=self.test_lb_network['id'])[0] self.lb_subnet = network_resources.AttributeDict(subnet) else: self.test_lb_network = self.create_network(self.lb_network) self.lb_subnet = self.create_subnet(self.test_lb_network) self.lb_subnet_id = self.lb_subnet.get('id') self.lb_tenant_id = self.lb_subnet.get('tenant_id') self.load_balancer = self._create_load_balancer( tenant_id=self.lb_tenant_id, vip_subnet_id=self.lb_subnet_id, wait=True) self.load_balancer_id = self.load_balancer.get('id') # self.subnet = self.create_subnet(self.network) # self.subnet_id = self.subnet.get('id') # self.tenant_id = self.subnet.get('tenant_id') # self.load_balancer = self._create_load_balancer( # tenant_id=self.tenant_id, # vip_subnet_id=self.subnet_id, # wait=True) # self.load_balancer_id = self.load_balancer.get('id') # # for listeners self.listener_id = None self.listener_name = data_utils.rand_name(name='listener') self.listener_description = data_utils.rand_name( name='listener_description') self.connection_limit = data_utils.rand_int_id(1000000, 9999999) self.default_pool_id = None self.loadbalancers = [{'id': self.load_balancer.get('id')}] self.protocol = random.choice(["TCP", "HTTP", "HTTPS"]) self.admin_state_up = True self.port_listener = 80 self.create_listener_kwargs = { 'name': self.listener_name, 'description': self.listener_description, 'loadbalancer_id': self.load_balancer_id, 'protocol': self.protocol, 'protocol_port': self.port_listener, 'connection_limit': self.connection_limit, 'admin_state_up': self.admin_state_up } # for pools self.pool_id = None self.pool_name = data_utils.rand_name(name='pool') self.pool_description = data_utils.rand_name(name='pool_description') self.lb_algorithm = 'ROUND_ROBIN' self.session_persistence = None self.admin_state_up = True self.listeners = [] self.members = [] self.healthmonitor_id = None self.create_pool_kwargs = { 'name': self.pool_name, 'description': self.pool_description, 'lb_algorithm': self.lb_algorithm, 'session_persistence': self.session_persistence, 'protocol': self.protocol, 'loadbalancer_id': self.load_balancer_id, 'admin_state_up': self.admin_state_up } # for members self.address = "127.0.0.1" self.weight = 100 self.member_id = None self.port_member = 80 # create member on the same subnet as load balancer self.create_member_kwargs = { 'address': self.address, 'protocol_port': self.port_member, 'subnet_id': self.subnet_id, 'weight': self.weight, 'admin_state_up': self.admin_state_up } def tearDown(self): self._try_delete_resource(self._delete_pool, self.pool_id) self._wait_for_load_balancer_status( load_balancer_id=self.load_balancer_id) self._try_delete_resource(self._delete_listener, self.listener_id) self._wait_for_load_balancer_status( load_balancer_id=self.load_balancer_id) super(TestNetworkTopology, self).tearDown() def _get_network_by_name(self, network_name): net = self._list_networks(name=network_name) self.assertNotEqual(len(net), 0, "Unable to get network by name: %s" % network_name) return network_resources.AttributeDict(net[0]) def _list_networks(self, *args, **kwargs): """List networks using admin creds """ from tempest.common import credentials_factory admin_manager = credentials_factory.AdminManager() self.networks_client_admin = admin_manager.networks_client # self.ports_client_admin = admin_manager.ports_client networks_list = self.networks_client_admin.list_networks( *args, **kwargs) return networks_list['networks'] def _list_subnets(self, *args, **kwargs): """List subnets using admin creds """ from tempest.common import credentials_factory admin_manager = credentials_factory.AdminManager() self.subnets_client_admin = admin_manager.subnets_client subnets_list = self.subnets_client_admin.list_subnets( *args, **kwargs) return subnets_list['subnets'] def _check_listener_attributes(self, listener): self.assertEqual(self.listener_name, listener['name']) self.assertEqual(self.listener_description, listener['description']) self.assertEqual(self.tenant_id, listener['tenant_id']) self.assertEqual(self.protocol, listener['protocol']) self.assertEqual(self.port_listener, listener['protocol_port']) self.assertEqual(self.connection_limit, listener['connection_limit']) self.assertEqual(self.default_pool_id, listener['default_pool_id']) self.assertEqual(self.admin_state_up, listener['admin_state_up']) self.assertEqual(self.loadbalancers, listener['loadbalancers']) def _check_pool_attributes(self, pool): self.assertEqual(self.tenant_id, pool['tenant_id']) self.assertEqual(self.pool_name, pool['name']) self.assertEqual(self.pool_description, pool['description']) self.assertEqual(self.protocol, pool['protocol']) self.assertEqual(self.lb_algorithm, pool['lb_algorithm']) self.assertEqual(self.session_persistence, pool['session_persistence']) self.assertEqual(self.admin_state_up, pool['admin_state_up']) self.assertEqual(self.listeners, pool['listeners']) self.assertEqual(self.members, pool['members']) self.assertEqual(self.healthmonitor_id, pool['healthmonitor_id']) def _check_member_attributes(self, member): self.assertEqual(self.address, member['address']) self.assertEqual(self.port_member, member['protocol_port']) self.assertEqual(self.subnet_id, member['subnet_id']) self.assertEqual(self.weight, member['weight']) self.assertEqual(self.admin_state_up, member['admin_state_up']) def _create_listener_with_port(self): listener = self._create_listener(**self.create_listener_kwargs) self.listener_id = listener['id'] self.addCleanup(self._try_delete_resource, self._delete_listener, self.listener_id) self._check_listener_attributes(listener) listener = self.listeners_client.get_listener(self.listener_id) self._check_listener_attributes(listener) return self.listener_id def _create_pool_from_listener(self, listener_id): self.create_pool_kwargs['listener_id'] = listener_id pool = self._create_pool(**self.create_pool_kwargs) self.pool_id = pool['id'] self.addCleanup(self._try_delete_resource, self._delete_pool, self.pool_id) self._check_pool_attributes(pool) pool = self.pools_client.get_pool(self.pool_id) self._check_pool_attributes(pool) return self.pool_id def _create_member_with_port(self, pool_id): member = self._create_member(pool_id=pool_id, **self.create_member_kwargs) self.member_id = member['id'] self.addCleanup(self._try_delete_resource, self._delete_member, pool_id, self.member_id) self._check_member_attributes(member) member = self.members_client.get_member(pool_id, self.member_id) self._check_member_attributes(member) return self.member_id def test_create_listener_and_member_with_port(self): self.create_listener_kwargs['protocol_port'] = self.port_listener if self.port_listener > 65535 or self.port_listener <= 0: self.assertRaises(ex.BadRequest, self._create_listener, **self.create_listener_kwargs) else: # Create Listener listener_id = self._create_listener_with_port() self.listeners = [{'id': listener_id}] # Create Pool self._create_pool_from_listener(listener_id) self.create_member_kwargs['protocol_port'] = self.port_member if self.port_member > 65535 or self.port_member <= 0: self.assertRaises(ex.BadRequest, self._create_member, self.pool_id, **self.create_member_kwargs) members = self.members_client.list_members(self.pool_id) # check that no members actually created self.assertFalse(len(members), "Member was not supposed to be created!") else: # Create Member self._create_member_with_port(self.pool_id)

commit_message:
Deprecate migration flags parameters

The correct live and block migration flags can be inferred
from the new live_migration_tunnelled config option.
live_migration_flag and block_migration_flag will be removed
to avoid potential misconfiguration.

Change-Id: I523d351900ee7852875e94e1d5d5cffb76935f11
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/93/337393/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Remove auth_host option

The auth_host option has been removed in server.pp,
so we should delete it in README.md.

subject: Skip INVALID and UNASSIGNED ofport in vlan restore
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-24 01:02:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/1f2e0b1055c690f99cd9ad0980d1dc8440cb0479', 'message': 'Use get_vif_port_set in restore_local_vlan_map

get_vif_ports returns ports with INVALID and UNASSIGNED
ofports and get_vif_port_set does not. The main scan_ports
loop uses the latter so any INVALID ofports (i.e. ofport == -1)
will be treated as removed and have their local VLANs reclaimed.
So an INVALID ofport could have the same local VLAN as a new
port that was added after it had been reclaimed.

This was causing an error in the _restore_local_vlan_map function
since it was using get_vif_ports which would cause it to process
INVALID ports as well so it could get two network UUIDs using the
same VLAN.

This fixes it by using get_vif_port_set instead so it matches the
same behavior as scan_ports since it is responsible for deciding
which ports are added/removed which controls VLAN allocation.

Change-Id: I9d722fa4fabd467ded44d9cd291a3fa4d1af90f6
Closes-Bug: #1526974
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-06-24 05:53:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/d26cc2ba6a39e0167b69b5fa4f22a0d06dc7ba0d', 'message': 'Use get_vif_port_set in restore_local_vlan_map

loop uses the latter so any INVALID ofports (i.e. ofport == -1)
will be treated as removed and have their local VLANs reclaimed.
So an INVALID ofport could have the same local VLAN as a new
port that was added after it had been reclaimed.

This was causing an error in the _restore_local_vlan_map function
since it was using get_vif_ports which would cause it to process
INVALID ports as well so it could get two network UUIDs using the
same VLAN.

This fixes it by using get_vif_port_set instead so it matches the
same behavior as scan_ports since it is responsible for deciding
which ports are added/removed which controls VLAN allocation.

Closes-Bug: #1526974
Change-Id: I9d722fa4fabd467ded44d9cd291a3fa4d1af90f6

commit_message:
Skip INVALID and UNASSIGNED ofport in vlan restore

get_vif_ports returns ports with INVALID and UNASSIGNED
ofports and get_vif_port_set does not. The main scan_ports
loop uses the latter so any INVALID ofports (i.e. ofport == -1)
will be treated as removed and have their local VLANs reclaimed.
So an INVALID ofport could have the same local VLAN as a new
port that was added after it had been reclaimed.

This was causing an error in the _restore_local_vlan_map function
since it was using get_vif_ports which would cause it to process
INVALID ports as well so it could get two network UUIDs using the
same VLAN.

This fixes it by skipping INVALID and UNASSIGNED ofports in the
vlan restoration so it matches the behavior of scan_ports
(which is responsible for deciding which ports are added/removed
for VLAN allocation).

Closes-Bug: #1526974
Change-Id: I9d722fa4fabd467ded44d9cd291a3fa4d1af90f6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/42/333642/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: int_br.get_vif_port_set.return_value = [port1, port2]

commit_message:
Deprecate auth_region option

The auth_region options in the [DEFAULT] configuration section in
glance-api.conf are deprecated, and will be removed in the O release.

Change-Id: Ie50ab3371386691b72e25e1088198c05edb920b6

commit_message:
Remove obsolete flag from 'octane fuel-backup' command

Flag --admin-password was removed from fuel-backup command a while
ago, but the documentation was not updated.

Remove obsolete flag from documentation to avoid confusion.

Change-Id: I80a1b125516bbaf587dfbf4d38a7e02f5080b8bd
Closes-bug: 1597766
(cherry picked from commit 6ac4e7d196cb5a005e516d6261c9b747f34b408c)

added_lines: octane fuel-backup --to <path-to-archive> $ octane fuel-backup --to /tmp/fuel-backup.7.0.tar.gz

subject: Convergence: Fix concurrent update resource delete
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-12 13:00:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/8dc9e7c9f9c210e174f43de98e23bf46de051004', 'message': 'Convergence: Handle resource deletes during concurrent update

In concurrent update, handle resource deletes from previous traversal.

During concurrent updates, the current traversal might try to fetch a
resource that was just deleted from DB by the previous traversal.

Change-Id: I0b36ce098022560d7fe01623ce7b66d1d5b38d55
Closes-Bug: #1528560
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-02-19 14:18:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/be46723d9cc765e7e987463e3f0dcd123585f92a', 'message': 'Convergence: Handle resource deletes during concurrent update

In concurrent update, handle resource deletes from previous traversal.
During concurrent updates, the current traversal might try to fetch a
resource that was just deleted from DB by the previous traversal.

In convergence, wherein concurrent updates are possible, soft delete a
resource during resource delete operation so that the resource entry is
available in DB for the latest traversal if referenced.
All the soft deleted resources will be deleted when the stack has
completed its operation.

Change-Id: I0b36ce098022560d7fe01623ce7b66d1d5b38d55
Closes-Bug: #1528560
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-03-08 09:13:12.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/499c9feda3f2134529a0593dc32e5af9e4a1894b', 'message': 'Convergence: Handle resource deletes during concurrent update

All the soft deleted resources will be deleted when the stack has
completed its operation.

Change-Id: I0b36ce098022560d7fe01623ce7b66d1d5b38d55
Closes-Bug: #1528560
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2016-03-17 17:42:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/0b9e861f90637e18df4b730271b57364e5168b40', 'message': "Convergence: Handle resource deletions during concurrent update

In convergence, wherein concurrent updates are possible, if a resource
is deleted (by previous traversal) after dependency graph is created
for new traversal, the resource remains in graph but wouldn't be
available in DB for processing.
It is prerequisite to have resources in DB before any action can be
taken on them.

Hence during convergence resource delete action, the resource entry
from DB is not deleted i.e soft deleted, so that the latest/new update
can find the entry.
All of these soft deleted resources will be deleted when the stack has
completed its operation.

Change-Id: I0b36ce098022560d7fe01623ce7b66d1d5b38d55
Closes-Bug: #1528560

commit_message:
Convergence: Fix concurrent update resource delete

In convergence, wherein concurrent updates are possible, if a resource
is deleted (by previous traversal) after dependency graph is created
for new traversal, the resource remains in graph but wouldn't be
available in DB for processing.
It is prerequisite to have resources in DB before any action can be
taken on them.

Hence during convergence resource delete action, the resource entry
from DB is not deleted i.e soft deleted, so that the latest/new update
can find the entry.
All of these soft deleted resources will be deleted when the stack has
completed its operation.

Closes-Bug: #1528560
Change-Id: I0b36ce098022560d7fe01623ce7b66d1d5b38d55
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/20/279520/21 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: mock_init.assert_called_once_with(res.delete) res.delete = mock.Mock() self.assertFalse(res.delete.called)

commit_message:
Remove obsolete flag from 'octane fuel-backup' command

Flag --admin-password was removed from fuel-backup command a while
ago, but the documentation was not updated.

Remove obsolete flag from documentation to avoid confusion.

Change-Id: I80a1b125516bbaf587dfbf4d38a7e02f5080b8bd
Closes-bug: 1597766
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-docs refs/changes/82/336482/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: octane fuel-backup --to <path-to-archive> $ octane fuel-backup --to /tmp/fuel-backup.7.0.tar.gz

subject: Fix mysql setup for Xenial jobs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-05 12:45:33.000000000', 'files': ['jenkins/jobs/macros.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/7b7bce7249c970cf6ca3ea73b271a114abfc9287', 'message': 'Fix mysql setup for Xenial jobs

On xenial with mysql5.7, running "mysql -h localhost" works, but
"mysql -h 127.0.0.1" doesn't, so change the setup call accordingly.

Change-Id: I5398889b0b7b75e4357bf91aa2c9b5e1594cd368
'}]
commit_message:
Fix mysql setup for Xenial jobs

On xenial with mysql5.7, running "mysql -h localhost" works, but
"mysql -h 127.0.0.1" doesn't, so change the setup call accordingly.

Change-Id: I5398889b0b7b75e4357bf91aa2c9b5e1594cd368
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/48/337648/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sudo -H mysql -u root -p$DB_ROOT_PW -h localhost -e "

commit_message:
Move rabbit option settings from DEFAULT to oslo_messaging_rabbit

oslo.messaging has deprecated the use of rabbit_* option settings
at the [DEFAULT] section in config file. This commit moves
the rabbit option settings to a [oslo_messaging_rabbit] section in
each of the relevant trove service when run 'devstack/plugin.sh'.

Closes-Bug: 1528391
Change-Id: Id60ea94a53ad96293846f252201416ad5b8e833d
